statement.text: This example calculates the enormous gap between the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the Planck energy scale. The LHC collides protons at 13 TeV center-of-mass energy, while the Planck energy is 1.22 × 10¹⁹ GeV - a factor of nearly 10¹⁵ (a million billion) times larger. This demonstrates why direct tests of quantum gravity are currently impossible.
statement.key_result: E_Planck / E_LHC ≈ 10¹⁵ - the experimental gap to quantum gravity

energy_ratio.interpretation: Planck energy is ~1 million billion times higher than LHC

length_ratio.interpretation: LHC probes 10¹⁶ times larger than Planck length

what_would_it_take.question: What accelerator would reach Planck energy?

brute_force.required_circumference: LHC is 27 km → Would need ~10¹⁵ × 27 km = 10¹⁶ km
brute_force.comparison: That's ~1 light-year circumference (distance to nearest star = 4 light-years)

cosmic_rays.note: Even the most energetic cosmic rays are 10⁷× below Planck scale

realistic_approaches: Indirect tests via precision measurements (GUP effects)

historical_context.description: How humanity has climbed the energy ladder
historical_context.rate_of_progress: ~10× per 25 years; reaching Planck at this rate would take ~15 × 25 = 375 years!

key_insight.text: The 10¹⁵ gap between LHC and Planck energy is one of the largest unexplored regions in physics. We've explored energy scales from meV to TeV (15 orders of magnitude), but there are still 15 more orders to go before Planck. Most of physics between 10⁴ GeV and 10¹⁹ GeV is 'terra incognita' - we have theories (GUTs, supersymmetry, strings) but no data.
key_insight.implication: Quantum gravity will likely never be probed directly with accelerators - we need indirect methods

learning_objectives: Calculate ratio of Planck to LHC energy
Appreciate the 10¹⁵ experimental gap to quantum gravity

common_errors: Thinking we're 'close' to probing Planck physics
Missing that 10¹⁵ is an enormous factor
Not realizing cosmic rays are also far below Planck scale
physics_insights: LHC probes ~10⁻¹⁹ m; Planck scale is ~10⁻³⁵ m - factor of 10¹⁶
